gs1_mapping.justification: Organisational sustainability disclosures are narrative/metric assertions; GS1 standards do not define ESG reporting content or assurance criteria.
Organisational sustainability disclosures are narrative/metric assertions; GS1 standards do not define ESG reporting content or assurance criteria.
If disclosures must be attributable to specific legal entities/sites, a standard organisational/location identifier can support unambiguous referencing; GS1 does not define ESG attributes themselves.
Assurance engagement evidence is audit-process specific; GS1 provides no standard for audit engagement records.
Organisational/site identification may help reference the reporting entity boundary; ESRS disclosure semantics are outside GS1 scope.
Taxonomy alignment KPIs are financial/sustainability reporting constructs; GS1 identifiers may label entities but do not address KPI computation/reporting requirements.
Financial product disclosures are outside GS1 system scope; GS1 does not standardise financial instrument identifiers/disclosure templates.

Value-chain relationship datasets can benefit from standard party/location identification to reduce ambiguity across counterparties; due diligence content, risk assessment, and governance are outside GS1 scope.
Where impacts relate to supply-chain activities, an event model can structure “who/what/where/when” operational events; it does not evidence human-rights/environmental impacts by itself.

Mitigation/remediation actions are management measures not inherently supply-chain traceability events; GS1 event standards may record operational changes but are not designed as due-diligence action registries.
Product/batch attributes and compliance-related characteristics can be associated to product identifiers and shared as structured master data; linking can route to authoritative declarations.
Collection/return/recycling flows are event- and logistics-heavy; traceability/event capture with party/location identifiers supports chain-of-custody evidence.
Packaging characteristics can be expressed/transported as product master data tied to product identifiers; linking supports access to packaging compliance info.
Member State system performance data is governance/system reporting, not product-level supply chain identification/traceability domain.
SFDR disclosures are financial regulatory reporting; GS1 is not a disclosure standard for financial entities/products.
Advisory disclosure content is regulatory/financial; outside GS1 scope.

A due-diligence assertion is not created by GS1; product/party/shipment identification and event traceability can support evidence chaining. Core deforestation/legal proof needs additional geolocation/legal datasets beyond GS1.
gs1_mapping.sector_relevance: FMCG; DIY / Retail; Logistics / Transport; Cross-sector

gs1_mapping.justification: Transactional statements can be referenced via links and tied to parties; GS1 does not standardise the due-diligence statement content/schema or authority submission.
Shipment identity and event trails can support linking emissions calculations to specific consignments; emissions accounting inputs/calculations are outside GS1.
Regulatory certificate surrender is a customs/regulator transaction not addressed by GS1 supply chain standards.
HR/pay datasets are internal workforce data; GS1 is not designed for HR reporting.
HR/pay datasets are internal workforce data; GS1 is not designed for HR reporting.
The prohibition is a compliance assertion; GS1 can support identifying products and linking to due-diligence/attestation info, but does not prove forced-labour absence.
Investigation cooperation records are legal/enforcement process data; outside GS1's standard scope.

Digital Product Passport availability can be enabled via GS1 Digital Link resolving to DPP data; GTIN provides the unique product identifier; GDSN can synchronise DPP attributes across trading partners.

DPP content (product identification, sustainability info) can be structured as GDSN master data attributes and accessed via Digital Link data carrier; GS1 standards directly address the data carrier and accessibility requirements.

GTIN is the global standard for unique product identification at unit/batch level; SSCC for logistics units; Digital Link provides the URI structure linking identifier to DPP. GS1 directly fulfils the unique identifier requirement.
gs1_mapping.sector_relevance: Cross-sector; FMCG; DIY / Retail; Logistics / Transport

gs1_mapping.justification: Manufacturer compliance and technical documentation can be linked via GLN (manufacturer ID) and GTIN (product ID); GDSN can share compliance attributes; EPCIS can record production events. Ecodesign requirement content itself is outside GS1 scope.
